         Sam looked out the small bars of his kennel wishing that at least someone would adopt him. He was only a year and a half old but looked to be about three. He gets along with the people at the shelter and does not mind the other dogs so he just sits there waiting for anything to happen since today he has a feeling that something good will happen.
         He perks up when he hears some footsteps that were not normal instead of the single person he usually heard he heard about three more sets. He got up seeing a young man, woman and in between them was a young...

The boy was humming looking at all of the dogs as he passed by all of them shaking his head until the boy reached his kennel. The boy smiled upon seeing sam and pointed to him âmommy daddy I want that one!â he said and both of the adults looked over the dog and said âalright Kaiâ and the person leading them through the pound opened Samâs cage and led him out by a lead. They had paid for Sam and filled out all of the paperwork and Kai had rode with him in the back seat petting the dog all over and hugging âsuch a good boyâ he said happily as he rubbed the shepherdâs head softly thinking. âwhen we get home we are going to have some funâ Kai whispered into Samâs ear as he rode with him. Sam wondered what the boy was thinking waiting for them to get home before finding out but Kai already had a plan to...
11111.title: Boy

111112.content:
As Sam's new family took him home, Kai squirmed around in his seat excitedly. Kai's parents were both very happy that their son was so excited to have a dog. He had been asking about getting one for months. What they didn't know was that Kai had BIG ideas. It all started a few years ago, when Kai was about 8. He saw a cartoon in which a character fattened up their pet dog until he was a big, squishy blob of blubber big enough to lay down on. The image stuck in his mind, and every time he saw that episode he would lean in close and gaze at the screen during that part, imagining how it would feel to snuggle up to all that furry fat. Time and time again, he's find an episode of a cartoon where a character packs on pounds, but they always find a way to shed it all by the end of the episode, leaving Kai disappointed and wondering "Why can't they just stay fat? It looks cool!" But nothing would top the excitement he'd feel when it was a dog, or any animal for that matter.

A year ago, when his parents first mentioned that they had thought about getting a pet, Kai's mind immediately flew to that scene with the boy laying on top of his fattened dog. Could he achieve that? Could he even have a chubby dog? Kai wasn't dumb, he knew that his parents wouldn't get a dog just so he could fatten it into oblivion, but what if... Kai then began to bring up how much he wanted a dog, and now he had one!

Kai down at Sam, who was still resting in his lap. He was thin. Not dangerously so, but Kai could feel his ribs. As he stroked Sam behind the ears, Kai imagined how it would feel if his hands were running through rolls of blubber, squishing them between his fingers, or how heavy Sam would feel in his lap if he was so big his belly hoisted his legs off the ground. "Soon, boy." Kai whispered.

"Huh?" Kai's mother said from the front seat.

"Oh, just telling Sam we'll be home soon!" Kai said as embarrassment flushed his cheeks slightly red. "By the way, what's for dinner?"
111112.title: Make the dog massive

choices: Kai tells Bryan about his plans for Sam.
Kai asks Bryan about his weight gain.
1111122.content:
A week had gone by since Sam's adoption and he could be happier! The german shepherd was already well adjusted to his new life, getting used to using the bathroom outside and new meal times. Kai had mentioned to his parents how thin Sam looked, and they agreed that he seemed a bit underweight, so Kai's mother purchased a formula of dog food designed to help underweight dogs achieve a healthier size. Kai also asked if he could take some responsibilities with Sam, like feeding him. His parents were impressed and gladly let Kai manage feeding and walking Sam.

Kai took full advantage of these opportunities. He'd keep Sam's food bowl full as much as he could, always leaving a bit extra for him to eat, enough that it looked like Sam had left scraps when in fact he had already eaten a meal and a half. He'd mix some sugar in Sam's water bowl as well, figuring it would help speed along Sam's growth. Every now and then Kai would be able to save leftovers from his own dinner and pass them off to Sam without his parents seeing.

Kai was hoping he could get Sam used to eating large quantities of food. He recalled that in the cartoon he loved, the character fattened their dog by not just feeding him fattening human food, but a lot of it, and the dog began to expect large servings and lots of calories. Even if Kai couldn't order a pizza just for Sam so long as his parents were around, he could at least do his best to get Sam used to being stuffed.

In the week Sam had spent with Kai's family he had fattened up to an average weight. He wasn't fat, or even chubby, but Kai could feel that there was more meat on the dog's bones. It was enough that Kai was encouraged, and he looked forward to seeing how Sam would develop and how far/fat he could go!

Kai sat on the couch, still in his pyjamas, watching tv with Sam under his arm. His jet black hair was messy, dangling almost in his eyes, and his pyjamas didn't quite fit right, as he was outgrowing them. Kai was neither chubby nor thin, but a soft average. He looked around, checking to see if anyone was nearby, and seeing that nobody was, reached into a nearby bag of potato chips, grabbed a few and fed them to Sam, who chomped them up and nuzzled into his beloved human, who smiled in return.

Kai's mother entered the room and smiled as well, appreciating how much Kai loved having Sam around. She them remembered something, and put on her mother persona. "Kai, I told you to get dressed! Bryan is going to be over soon!"

Bryan was Kai's best friend. Their parents knew each other from college and had stayed close. Bryan was coming over to spend the weekend while their parents went off to a mini-vacation they had planned. They were supposed to have a babysitter, but she canceled at the last minute and their parents decided that the two boys should be alright for two days. They had to start learning to be responsible at some point, and if there was anything they needed they had a list of numbers they could call.

Kai nodded to his mother and hoisted himself up off the couch. Once in his room Kai undressed and went to pick out his clothes. Before slipping on his shirt, Kai examined his body in the mirror. He recalled that in the cartoon, as the dog got fatter, so did the boy who fattened him. Kai poked his stomach. It wasn't flat, but it wasn't chubby. The young boy wondered what it'd feel like to grow a belly of his own. Well, Sam's belly was the priority. Kai slipped on a neat polo shirt and slipped into the bathroom to comb his hair before returning to the couch to snuggle with Sam.

A few minutes later, Bryan arrived. Bryan was 12, a year older than Kai. He had short, dusty brown hair and grey/blue eyes. The last time Kai had seen Bryan was a few months ago. Back then, the two friends were the same height, but now Kai could see that Bryan had grown a few inches taller.

Bryan had also grown a few inches around the midsection. He was wearing a shirt Kai hadn't seen on him before, and it seemed to be the next size up, but it rested on his belly in a way that lightly showed the indentation of his belly button. His stomach poked out a few inches. Most noticeably, Bryan's face had rounded out and he had the start of a second chin. There was no mistaking it, Bryan had gotten a bit chubby.

Kai stood, rooted to the spot for a split second, rapidly scanning his friend with his eyes. Bryan extended his arms and pulled Kai in for a big hug. "Hey man, I missed you!" Bryan said. His voice sounded a little different, as if it had begun changing.

"Oh, hi Bryan! Long time no see!" Kai said, snapping out of his trance. He let his arms wrap around his friend. "Soft..." he thought to himself.

"Alright you two," Kai's father started, "You know you can call us at any time if something is wrong. We won't be more than an hour away, and you can call the neighbors if you need to. All the numbers are on the fridge. All the food you'll need is in there, but there's money on the counter just in case. Kai, Sam should have enough to make it through the weekend too, but if not the pet store is close enough that I'm fine with you walking. Any questions?" The boys shook their heads. "Alright, stay safe and have a good time, you two!" And with that, Kai's parents headed out the door, leaving the two boys alone for the weekend.
1111122.title: A Week Later...

choices: "I brought some extra cash for food!"
11111221.content:
Kai and Bryan plopped down on the couch with Sam between them.

"So this is Sam?" Bryan said, scratching the dog behind the ears.

"Yep! We got him just last week and he's already the best dog ever!" Kai replied.

"Oh, he sure is!" Bryan said, cooing the dog who was panting happily from the attention. Sam then flipped around and grabbed the bag of potato chips Kai had been feeding him earlier and stuck his head in, lapping at the salty, oily snacks. "Oh, Sam, stop that!" Bryan laughed. "Aren't you going to stop him?" He turned to Kai, whose eyes were glued to the dog.

"Nah, let him have his fun. This weekend is all about us having as much fun as we can! After all, no parents!" Bryan returned Kai's statement with a high five. Kai then paused for a moment before hesitantly adding "Besides, don't you think Sam would be cute if he were a little chubby?"

"Huh, you think so?" Bryan absentmindedly poked at his own soft tummy.

"Yeah, like do you remember that episode of Tim and Jeffrey? The one where the Tim feeds his dog and makes him chubby?"

"Yeah, of course! It's like my favorite episode. But the dog in that episode didn't get a little chubby, he got huge!" Bryan extended his hands from his stomach for emphasis, as if he were holding a large belly in front of him.

"Well then..." Kai paused again and swallowed nervously. "What if Sam got that fat?" Kai's face flushed red as he waited for Bryan's reply, which came in a mere second.

"Oh, that'd be cool." Bryan responded casually, patting Sam's back.

"R-really? You think so?" Kai stammered.

"Yeah, he'd be all soft and cuddly! And he'd probably love the food. Too bad you can't really fatten up a dog that much." Bryan sighed wistfully.

"Well what if you could?"

"Huh?"

Kai clenched his hands into his pants. He wasn't so sure why admitting this to his friend was so... embarrassing. It brought heat to his face, caused his heart to race and his palms to sweat. "I've.... I've been fattening Sam up. I really want to make him fat so I can have a fat dog like in Tim and Jeffrey. I've wanted that for so long, it's the reason I wanted a dog so badly. And last week Sam was really thin and now he's not, so it's working! I could make him super fat!"

"Cool." Bryan said again, casually.

"S-so you don't think it's weird? You don't think I'm crazy?"

"No man, I think it's cool! We should totally see how much we can feed Sam over the weekend. Oh that reminds me."

"Yeah?" Kai, now reaffirmed, leaned in to hear Bryan's reply.
11111221.title: Kai tells Bryan about his plans for Sam.

111112211.content:
"I had brought some cash over for some food for us. Remember my birthday was last week so I decided to take some of it and bring it over so that we could spend it on some food." Bryan said triumphantly as he pulled out two twenty dollar bills and a single ten out from his pocket showing it to Kai before putting it back into his pocket "So what are our plans for this lovely little doggie?" he said looking down at Sam who was still munching on the chips.

Kai thought for a moment running a hand down the dogs flank and squeezing a small layer of flab "well I have one Idea." he said as he looked over to Bryan. Bryan had perked up at Kai's comment "well spit it out already!" he said already excited for what the idea was going to be.

Kai looked at the dog for a bit and smiled a bit "well the pet store down the street sells this new brand of dog food and I read on the internet that the dog food is highly fattening. Some people began to buy the stuff in bulk and now their dogs look a lot bigger then before. I thought that since the food isn't that expensive we could get that and also get some pizzas not only for ourselves but for lovely sam over here and that way we could fatten him up with not only the kibble but also the pizza." Kai finished off with a bit of a chuckle recalling some of the pictures that the owners of the dogs who baught the dog kibble posted showing ther bloated and fattened pooche's.

Bryan looked over at Kai and begain to think nodding a bit before saying
111112211.title: "I brought some extra cash for food!"

choices: Wonder why there are so many leftovers.
1111122111.content:
Bryan wholeheartedly nodded and approved before he added, "But keep it slow, okay? We can't have your parents finding out about our project, right?" Kai nodded and called up the pizza place, "Hi, uh, I'd like an order for delivery, please." The man on the phone responded, "Ok, by credit or debit?" Kai froze. "Can I pay with cash?" he asked. "Sorry," the cashier responded, "No, store policy." Kai nodded, "Ok, can I at least place an order then?" When the man responded affirmatively, Kai continued, "Ok, I need two extra large whatever-you-call the all-meat pizzas."

         "Will that complete you order? Or would you like the complementary two-liter of Pepsi to go with it?" Kai assented, so the cashier continued, "Ok, that'll be $13.52. Is that ok? What name shall I put this order under?" When Kai told the man his name, the man thanked Kai and hung up. "That was easy; and, fortunately, the pizza place is only about 5 blocks from here," Kai told Bryan, who then suggested, "Maybe we could bring Sam."

         Kai considered and replied, "Why not? I've heard it's good to get dogs to exercise occasionally to increase their hunger and to keep them in good shape. We don't want Sam to be out of shape, just nice and soft." Bryan agreed, and the three went off to the pizza place.

         The real reason Kai had brought Sam was to get Sam the free burgers that a struggling burger joint gave away to try and promote its product. Kai and Bryan would get burgers, and Kai was sure he could get one for Sam too. Thus, when the trio walked by the place, and the man asked whether the kids wanted a burger, he even offered Sam a free burger without Kai's request, which Sam happily accepted.

         When the boys reached the pizza place, they stood outside and covertly fed Sam their burgers, which he happily received. When Kai's name was called, he went and got the pizzas and payed for them before he gave the pizzas to Bryan and held the Pepsi and Sam's leash. Walking back, Sam seemed a tad discomforted by the food he had inhaled and flopped on the ground while the boys ate their pizza.

         Only when Kai offered Sam a piece of pizza did the dog revive and snap up the greasy mess and swallow it whole and belch contentedly before he went and lay with Kai and Bryan on the couch on which he ate chips and slept. And the three boys sat, ate, fed Sam, and rubbed the dog's belly. Sam wished every day were like this one.

         To the boys' mild disappointment and later relief, Sam didn't seem to gain much noticebable weight. But when the two days were done, there were considerable leftovers to be had: Pizza, Chinese food, burgers and fries, and a liter of Pepsi, the first liter of which had been given to Sam in small quantities over the two days. And to Kai, Sam felt slightly softer and more comfortable. Sam, who was barely two-years-old and had liged emaciated for much of that time, now felt loved and healthy for the first time in his life.

         When the boys' parents got home, theyâ€¦
1111122111.title: "Thats a great idea!"

11111221111.content: From that day forward, Kai's parents never noticed Sam's slowly mounting weight gain. And thusâ€¦
11111221111.title: Notice no difference in Sam.

111112211111.content:
And because Kai's parents failed to notice Sam's slow, yet linear weight increase, Kai's mother called to her chubby twelve-year-old son, "Kai, come on! We need to take Sam to the vet!" Kai was dreased and ready to go, but the announcement surprised him. At first, he was worried, but he pondered and found no reason to believe that his parents had discovered his ploy. So Kai rode along, stroking his dog's soft, ample flanks, which dimpled slightly when Sam sat, a phenomenon Kai found rather cute.

         When they arrived at the vet, Kai snatched and discreetly fed Sam a few complimentary treats which the vet offered. Sam snatched them eagerly; and after a short wait, Sam was called into the examination room, where the doctor administered the shots, which required a few bribes of food to coax Sam into allowing.

         Then came the crucial part. The doctor took Sam's height, a few other metrics, and finally, Sam's weight. The doctor sighed, a sound only Kai and Sam heard. Sam was an average sized German Shepherd, standing 25 inches at the withers, the doctor noted before saying, "He's 107 pounds; he should weigh, at most, 85. I think he's 22 pounds overweight."

         Fortunately, Kai's mother became defensive and retorted calmly, "Well, maybe he's just a big dog. We give him just 2 and 1/2 cups twice a day, right Kai?" When Kai nodded, she continued, "And he gets zero tablescraps and daily walks. What more can I do? We don't have the money for an expensive hypothyroidism test either."

         The doctor stuttered and looked speechless, "If that's the case, I don't know; just reduce his food more. I don't know." When the doctor walked out, Kai's mother looked smug and said, "Come on, boys, let's get out of here. And for being good boys, what would you both like for lunch? We'll show that doctor."

         Having eaten at Wendy's, the boys were relaxing on the couch when Kai was feeding Sam a chip as his mother walked in. "Kai? Did you just give Sam a chip?" To not sound defensive, Kai nonchalantly responded, "No, I fumbled and dropped it; and Sam rightfully got it." Seeming unconvinced, Sam's mother continued to eye Kai suspiciously before she forgot about the whole incident.

         But Kai never forgot this, and he grew more paranoid about Sam's weight; and yet, Kai's parents never grew suspicious. They always questioned the doctor's judgment and always believed Kai that Sam was only fed limited portions of 5 cups a day, the minimum recommended amount on the bag, despite that the reality was that Sam's portions and scraps intake increased slowly and steadily over the years.

         At four years old, Sam weighed 126 pounds; at five, 138 pounds; and at 6, he weighed 160 pounds. By the time he was seven, however, Kai was sixteen, and had a job; but Kai still cared as deeply about Sam and his goal as he always had. Although Kai knew he had accomplished his goal, he wondered whether he could continue.

         But over time, the burger joint of Kai's youth had failed; and Kai had become increasingly chubby and lazy, walking Sam less and less, a phenomenon which displeased Sam at first; but later, with Sam's achy, creaking joints, Sam would come to appreciate. At this point, Sam was twice his "ideal" weight and was quite hefty, with flanks that protruded outward, instead of forming an hourglass shape which they would have ideally.

         But one day, when Sam tried to shift his bulk to get up, he found that his joints ached more than usual, so he nudged Kai for help. Kai nodded and fed Sam a chip, which Sam happily accepted before he nudged Kai again. Kai understood Sam this time and got up to put Sam outside. When Sam didn't follow, Kai realized what Sam needed. So he grabbed a towel, shifted Sam under it, and waddled with Sam to the door.

         Unfortunatelyâ€¦
111112211111.title: Skip ahead (to conflict).

1112.content: Do you want to follow the story of Saxe, a seven-year-old lab who tells his story via first person pronouns? Or follow some other lab?
1112.title: Labrador

11121.content:
I just keep eating. I could stop myself at any time, but I choose to not stop. Never mind that I may be double the weight that my vet says I should be, never mind that I take an entire minute to stand on my own, and never mind that I can walk no more than ten steps without having to lie down, exhausted from my own weight. If there is food, I will eat it; and I wouldn't trade any morsel of food for the world.
         At least now I can say that I have sympathetic owners. Things weren't always so for me. So to understand why I feel compelled to eat every scrap of food my owners give me, I must inform you of my past. My dreary, dismal past.
         I remember nothing about my mother except that she always taught me to apreciate edible ever given to me, a skill that would serve me well in the future. I was born, my dear reader, in a grimy, malodorous slum-alley that smelled of human urine, vomit, feces, and alcohol. Yes, I was born a stray, not something that I'm proud of.
         In case my dear reader hadn't gathered, I am a dog, specifically, a Black Labrador Retriever. I am not sure of my place of origin, nor even where I am now. These things were never important to me, so I never found out. I am a standard twenty-three inches at the withers and 163 pounds, I know, more than double my ideal weight according to breed standard. My name is Saxe. At least, that was the name given to me by my previous owners.
         Speaking of whom, when I was born, as soon as we were weened, my mother left. I harbor no resentments because, in complete candor, I would have done the same thing. We were a nuisance and a burden to her, so she had no reason to keep us.
         But, anyway, when I was hot, hungry, and alone with my siblings, a man came when I was sleeping and picked me up. I of course awoke and squirmed around, but his grip was ironclad. He brought me to his truck, which smelled of tobacco. Not a pleasant smell, but still better than my previous habitat. The man drove like a madman, which is why I am still hesitant inside a car to this day.
         When the truck stopped and I got out, I discovered that we were in the middle of nowhere. Stixville, we shall call it. And I immediately new that something was off. Inside, I could hear an older and a younger woman's voices yelling at the top of their lungs. Immediately, the man barged in, started yelling at the both of them to shut up. A shouting match ensued, followed by a loud slap that I only heard, because I was cowering in the corner, afraid for my life. Eventually, the shouting reached a climax before it died off.
         Then, I noticed a boy, perhaps, in human years, 14 or 15, who picked me up and tried to soothe me. But by his own trembling, I could tell that he was afraid too. He took me into his room and tried his best to comfort me. The boy was the only solace that I had in that house. He was a quiet, thougtful boy who talked to himself a lot about things that I didn't begin to understand. But I enjoyed his company and he seemed to enjoy mine. He also tried to feed me as often as he could, butâ€¦
11121.title: Saxe

111211.content:
Perhaps I should inform you of the man's worst characteristics. By far, his worst was his emotional volatility. There were times where, for days at a time, he would leave me outside, with little food or water; but out of the blue, he would let me inside and give me all the food that I wanted and let me do as I pleased. I am to this day scared of that man just thinking of him. The boy was also scared of him; why, I never found out. All I knew was that the man would come into the boys room at night occasionally and throw me outside.
         The boy fed me outside whenever the man was not home and I was outside. I was conditooned to eat as much as I could whenever I could. The boy was caught once and, I assume, severely reprimanded. The boy also fed me human food whenever he could. I remember that he also enjoyed food and had a soft pad of fat on his stomach that made him a comfortable pillow. My weight went in cycles. But slowly, very slowly, I managed to gain a tiny bit of weight.
         I was in that house for years, until, one day, a man whom I had never seen before saw me in the back yard chained, muddy, and looking half-starved, and he took me to an animal shelter. He also took the boy, but somewhere else. I haven't seen either of them since.
         The animal shelter was a dingy, overcrowded place. Donations were never enough to cover the cost of food for all of us completely; so I was constantly hungry. I was never walked for longer than five minutes every three hours. My cage was too small for me. I never became vicious, only defensive. I still don't completely trust humans because of these experiences. I trust my current master more than anyone else, but I am still occasionally suspicious of him.
         After perhaps a year, maybe six months, I lost track to be honest, until I met my current owner. He looked fully grown, but still young for a human. He wears the same thing every day: a plain gray suit with a white shirt and a black tie and black shoes. Whenever he is not in that uniform, he wears blue jeans and t-shirts that reveal the soft pads of soft tissue which the boy had, but slightly larger. He vaguely resembles the boy, but not really. He lives alone, except for me.
         When my master came for me, he seemed to know that I was his dog. He walked over to me immediately and helped me out of the crate. He took me into his car and drove me to a house in a small town where I live today. Not much of note has happened to me in my life. I get fed whenever I want, I nap whenever I want, and the man pets me whenever I want and he is home. He does leave sometimes, but usually just for an hour or two. I miss him dearly, but I am only thinking about my past today because the man has been gone for more than two hours.
         Wait, is that his car? I think that he is in the driveway now. Except thatâ€¦
111211.title: Continue with this story.

1112111.content:
I wasn't scared, I wasn't threatened, I didn't act aggresively. I was only a bit saddened. I knew that I would never be replaced, but I did feel like I now had to compete for attention. When Coburg, or Coby, as he would come to be called, first came home, I knew almost innately what was expected of me. I would have to teach him the ways, manners, and customs of our house. What was acceptable and what wasn't. I would teach him, perhaps most importantly, to appreciate food. I would never compete with Coby for food, but I would clean up after him if he left his food down for too long. My master would give us all the food we wanted, but only at certain times.
         I taught Coby that begging was not the best way to get food from our master; where to wait so that he would give us the most food. Coby, being a puppy, naturally wanted to play; but seeing that my old bones couldn't keep up with him, I began telling him the stories of my own life when Coby and I were alone. I could tell that Coby was enthralled by my stories; and that he could now see why I craved to always have food.
         After meals, Coby would curl up with his head either on my flank or on our master's abdomen, both made comfortable pillow for him. Perhaps I should inform you that Coby was a chocolate Labrador Retriever, similar to me in every physical way but hair color and stature. Coburg was a restless and curious puppy, usually getting himself into trouble while I slept, only to be discilplined by the master later. The master would play with him and walk the both of us occasionally, but he stopped after I nearly collapsed halfway through and was panting for fifteen minutes after we got home.
         Coby never really lost his puppy-fat though. It turned into adolescent fat, but that was the closest he ever got to his ideal weight. Eventually, he lost his puppylike playfulness and was happy to discuss with me how life was. I have watched Coby change from a cute puppy; to slightly chubby adolescent with a slight hourglass shape; to a more barrel-chested shape, to having a slight pear shape when he sits. He eats very well and gets more treats than I did after a year with the master.
         "Saxe," Coburg asked me as I pondered these things, "what purpose do we serve?" I looked up, confused, trying to scramble for an answer before I made a feeble response, "to serve our master in whatever way he likes." Coburg thought that over for a second before he asked again, "And what purpose are we serving for our master?" Saxe had an easy answer this time, "To provide him happiness and company," and Saxe added, "and look what we earn," he nudged the adipose on his flank, "luxury that our ancestors never dreamed possible. We have all the food that we like, all the affection, and with no effort required."
         I was quiet for a while before he asked again, "Do you ever feel like you're a slave?" I shook my head, "If I'm a slave, I'm the king of them because I have a standard of living that my forebearers would never have dreamed of." "But is there not more than food to life?" Coby asked, disconcerted by my answer, apparently. "What do you mean?" I asked, expectantly. "Well, don't you want to go back to nature, to the way things were before allâ€¦this?" Coby gestured to my ample physique. "No, I never really have. Have I ever told you about where I came from?"
         Coby nodded, "Many times." "That's 'the way things were' before all this," I responded. "That sounds fun," Coby nodded. "Yeah, until you try it," I responded with a chuckle and a shake of my head. His foolish optimism and naÃ¯vete would be the end of him. "Dogs die, every day, out there, Coburg," I whispered, in the most sympathetic tone I could muster, "I lost brothers and sisters out there. And my mother." Coby's face saddened, "Oh, I'm sorry." That's all we said of that issue.
1112111.title: He has a new puppy.

11121111.content:
I'm afraid my health is deteriorating, and Coby knows it. My knees hurt when I try and walk, the master has given me magical peanut butter that made the pain lessen considerably, but did not erase that I still have trouble with walking. I have started waking up in the middle of the night struggling for breath. When this happens, and fortunately it only happens once every few nights, mostly when I sleep on my stomach, I go over to my food bowl and eat what's left over, and whatever remains in Coby's bowl as well.
         I will not pretend that I do not know the cause of these problems, but I haven't the heart to try and stop these problems. I feel that to do something half-heartedly or unwittingly is foolish. If one wishes to be fat, accept the consequences and do not complain. I received many sidelong glances on my short walk the other day; I don't care. I am observant, but I don't care.
         Coburg keeps asking me "meaning of life questions." His heart is young and naÃ¯ve, full of youthful passion. He turned a year old today. The master celebrated like he celebrates all our birthdays. He divides the cake between us equally. My proportion is reduced, but I still love Coburg. The master got a bigger cake to compensate. I inhaled my piece rather quickly, so I watched Coby try and eat his piece. I watched as the small bubbles of fat that formed at his waist when he sat jiggle slightly as he tried to eat his cake.
         I could always tell when Coby was bored. He would always ask pointless questions like, "are we supposed to just sit here and slowly die?" His questions were always vaguely disconcerting but harmless. I was surprised when he turned and asked me, "Do you think that we are always being surveiled?" I chuckled and shook my head, "No, Coby, not always. Our master may control our lives, but his control is better than any alternative." Coby was never satisfied with my answers; he would always shake his head and try and fall back asleep. But this time he asked me, "Isâ€¦this lifeâ€¦really better than freedom?"
         Perhaps for the millionth time, I explained to him the advantages of our current life over a difficult life on the streets. "You're just bored and full of youthful energy," I told him, "You'll grow out of it." Coby looked at me for a second, "But I don't want to," he said to me, "I always want to be full of energy and young and restless." I chuckled again at Coby's optimism. "You face no challenges here," I replied, pointing out the problem with his proposal. "Maybe that's the problem," Coby replied, "I want a challenge."
11121111.title: Continue with this story.

111211111.content:
WARNING: MILDLY GRAPHIC CONTENT

         Coby disappears into the back yard for long stretches of time. Although these disappearances never worry our master, they worry me a good deal. I always think that Coby has either run away or is plotting some conspiracy to overthrow humanity. He does this intermittently, especially when I am asleep. He knows that I would never approve of his disappearing for more than a few minutes, call me smothering, I know. I am a loyal dog who loves his
master.
         Today, however, I managed to catch Coburg when he left the house today. Our master wasn't home, so I waited a couple of minutes and quietly pursued Coby. I should perhaps inform you, if you haven't deduced from my previous lectures, that I am woefully out of shape. I admit, my life has some drawbacks and is not for the faint of heart; but it is, to me, far more fulfilling. My first obstacle was getting out of the doggy door. I rarely have ever used it, partially because it is rarely open and partially because I had no use for it when humans were around.
         I heaved and squirmed for a few moments before I lay still. I then heaved and finally wriggled my abdomen through the wretched thing. It was quite painful, and I have no intention of using the door again. I'm sure that I have bruises from it. Fortunately, I was downwind from Coby and picked up his smell easily. I raced as quickly as I could, which seemed to me like an agonizing waddle, after Coby. Fortunately, Coby, despite his youth, seemed in no hurry to get to his destination. So I cauht and stalked Coby, who took a relatively straight path to the edge of our property and crossed under the fence at a whole that he seemed to have dug to accomodate me. I was pleased. But then I smelled a
smell that nearly made me convulse in sickness: the smell of dog's blood.
111211111.title: Continue with the story.

1112111111.content:
I had nearly forgotten how much I hated the smell of blood. I nearly blew my cover by almost coughing and gagging. But I forced myself to continue walking. It was a terrible, excruciating ordeal; the smell of blood grew stronger with each passing step. I forced myself to go on further, my astonishment helping me to ignore my pain. Coby started running, well trotting, because his bulk prevented him from sprinting outright, so I nearly lost him, because my own body so hindered my movement, as I have said, being overweight is not for the faint of heart.
         We finally arrived at a semi-clearing in the brush where I saw him for the first time. He was probably a Belgian Malinois or German Shepherd, but in far worse shape than I had ever been in. His ribs were visible to me from a moderate distance, despite his relatively heavy coat. He was chained to a stake, so I knew that this was no accident. He sensed as soon as I saw him. He looked over Coby's shoulder and growled. Coby turned and saw me.
         "Saxe," Coby began, before he nearly lost control of his composure. "Yes," I replied, "thus is the nature of the most despicable of humanity. Although humans are capable, like our owner, of doing good things, their natural state is unrefined and barbaric. Humanity has trained itself, at least some humans have, to do good; but some humans fall to this most primitive state of man. The one that does this."
         "Who are you," the chained dog snarled, "what do you know about the wretchedness of humanity? Look at you, the obese blob who is out of breath after having walked just a few hundred yards. You're a rich, spoiled lap dog who has never done anything with his life."
         "Perhaps you should listen, sir," I began, "I too, once had an abusive owner. Never likeâ€¦this; but he would chain me outside and starve me." "HA!" the other dog interrupted, "I bet that you mean that your owner once denied you a tablescrap and forced you to get your fat self off the couch to go outside." "Bowie, please," Coby interrupted; but I had slowly shuffled himself to reveal Bowie and Coby his back, down which ran a long, thin line, a scar from where his previous owner had once hit him with a beer bottle and the shards of glass had cut that line.
         "Do you need more evidence?" I finished. Bowie was silent after that. "We have to do something," Coby said. "What?" I snapped, "what can we do?" I replied. "We can get the master," Coburg responded. "That's a good plan, but how?" "I have an idea," Coby replied mysteriously.
1112111111.title: Continue

11121111111.content:
Coby and I, well, I was anyway, were thoroughly tired when we got back to the house. My joints ached, and I needed food. My master had filled our bowls I suppose when he left; so we both devoured their contents when I managed to squeeze through the doggy door. We waited patiently for our master to g et home. And when he got home, after he had checked on and fed us, he let us outside.
         "Ok," Coby whispered, "on three, we start barking. And when I say run, run as fast as you can toward Bowie, ok?" I nodded, unsure of whether the food in my stomach would stay there. "One," Coby counted, "two, â€¦ three!" Coby and I started barking together as loudly as they could. Eventually, the master came out to shush us, and Coby said, "Now!" and took off at his limbering trot toward Bowie. I forced myself up and started waddling after Coburg. The master soon followed. Our plan had worked.
         Our master kept trying to catch us; but because he was as out of shape as Coby, he could barely keep up with me. Eventually, I have to believe, he smelled the same smell we did: blood and unwashed flesh. Suddenly we entered Bowie's clearing; the master froze. He saw Bowie, who growled and showed his teeth. "Bowie!" Coby whispered, "Don't worry. It's the master. Don't worry; he's friendly."
         Suddenly, our master turned and fled. A few minutes later, he came back with the biggest bowl in our house filled to the brim with dog food, and a bag of potato chips. He shooed us away and set the bowl in front of Bowie. The dog ravenously ate, but only managed to eat a quarter, if that, of the bowl's contents. While that was happening, the master put the shiny metal object to his ear and spoke into it. At the end, he looked mildly disappointed and put the brick away. "Don't worry," the master said, "we'll be back tomorrow."
         And the next day came suddenly when a man came to the master's door and reported that he was from animal control. The master led the man to Bowie and came back carrying Bowie. The master from then on always seemed paranoid that he underfed us and gave us as many treats as we wanted. I was most pleased by this development, and Coby was also rather pleased.
         "You're right, Saxe," Coburg started one day, "I am very glad and fortunate to be in this house. I would much rather have enough to eat than to be free."
11121111111.title: Continue

111211111111.content:
N.B. THE STORY WILL HENCEFORTH BE TOLD FROM THE PERSPECTIVE OF COBURG (Coby). Please do not revert back to Saxe's point of view from here.

         I awoke to the sound of wheezing. It wasn't a new occurence for Saxe. Saxe rolled onto his middle, which spread like a cake beneath him when he did. Saxe can barely walk more than a few paces without having to rest from weariness. His fat forms large pads on his sides when he sits on his haunches, which he can only do for so long before he has to rest because he front legs tire just from that exertion. He spends most of his time sleeping nowadays. And when he is not sleeping, he is eating, doing his business, or talking to me.
         I am not particularly thin myself. I have small fat pads when I sit, and my body looks like a barrel, but I look nothing like Saxe, who looks like a rounded pear when he stands. Fat hangs down to his knees and his belly rubs the floor when he sits up. He always seems hot and sometimes wheezes without having exerted any effort. And he sometimes wakes up in the middle of the night like he did just now.
         I went back to sleep, and when I awoke, Saxe had not stirred. I went to eat breakfast; and when I arrived, Saxe still hadn't moved. I thought that this was strange. I called to him, "Saxe, come on, breakfast." That usually woke him, or at least made him stir, but this time, he still didn't move. I sank my paw into his flesh, cold as the room. That was definitely not right. I barked until the master came. I nudged Saxe; the master's face turned grim. He felt Saxe's heart; and I suppose felt nothing because he shed a tear. I nuzzled the master, who in turned lathered me with attention.
         When the autopsy report came in a week later, they diagnosed Saxe with a stroke. The master sighed and moved on. I learned to as well, but only by the help of someone else.
111211111111.title: Continue on.

1112111111111.content:
I felt acutely alone, and bored. He was continually hungry at increasingly short intervals and always ate when he could. Saxe had been right; I did lose his youthful energy. He could no longer run long distances without collapsing. His fat pads on his sides were now larger when he sat up. His stomach now definitively rested on the ground. The vet told the master that I needed to lose weight. My master paid her no mind; he loves me and thinks that I'm healthy. I think that I am too.
         Bowie came home today. He still has scars, but he looks moderately healthier than when I last saw him. His ribs are still easily felt, and sometimes visible. I hear the master mutter about how the people at the animal shelter try and keep their dogs underweight to save money and to arouse more pity for the animals. I believe him. Bowie is still untrusting of the master, but tolerates his touch. Bowie also eats so much that he says he feels nauseous. But he never actually vomits. I can see the food form a rock in his stomach.
         Bowie also contemplates how to be free of human control. When he isn't sleeping or eating, Bowie paces outside, pondering how to get back at humanity. "Why can't you see that some humans are good?" I ask him continually. "I just can't," was always his chorus. I sometimes gave up my food so that Bowie could eat when our master wasn't around. Bowie seemed to not want it at first, objecting that he knew how much I enjoyed my food; but he usually was coaxed into it, led by my insistence.
         Nevertheless, he pledged to run away. I noticed that at the same time he went from having a defined hourglass shape the vet wants me to have to a more cylindrical, healthy shape, he grew more insistent on running away. I tried to plead with him, but he insisted on running away. "Coburg," Bowie started one day, â€¦
1112111111111.title: Bowie.

11133111.content:
In a normal college campus stood a single person looking around as he smiled. It was the last day of classes and Mike just finished his finals and was ready to spend his summer at his apartment with his favorite husky Spike. The Husky was Mikes best and possibly closest friend considering that the husky was the only thing that he had left. Ever since he was little he was born into a wealthy family, and after he finished high school he was given a large sum of money leaving him very wealthy himself allowing him to pay for his own apartment, college, and pretty much anything he felt like without the worry of his parents or anyone else worrying about him or his spending.

As Mike walked into his apartment Spike trotted around the corner happily barking and running up to him. Spike was a very fit husky for his age muscle lining the canines body and his cloud soft and deep colored coat almost shone in the sunlit front room of his apartment. Mike slowly rubbed the husky's belly slowly grinning as the husky let out a few barks and playful growls the man and his dog still playing with each other in the doorway. Mike soon stopped playing with Spike before walking into his apartment closing the door behind him and throwing off his backpack onto the couch turning on the T.V. as he turned it on a news broadcast was finishing up with the reporter showing off a rather portly German shepherd.

"In other news, a new virus has been popping up all over the world. Dogs from all over the world are either bloating up with a mysterious slime and bursting from all of it or they are fattening up at dangerous rates." the reporter said in a monotone voice. Mike ignored the end of the broadcast opting to switch to another channel before surfing around for a few more minutes sighing. "well boy looks like there is nothing on" he said petting Spike on the head before grabbing the canines leash and hooking it to his collar "lets go to the dog park" Mike said happily patting the dog on the side walking out the house mike not caring about the news broadcast thinking that it was just a prank someone was pulling.

As Mike walked into the dog park there were a plethora of big dogs running around in their side of the park and upon Spike entering a German shepherd, Collie, Lab, Golden retriever and Belgian Malinois all walked over to the dog sniffing and barking for Spike to play. Mike giggled happily before removing the lead and letting the dogs play the news broadcast coming into the man's mind once again as he watched the canines play together.

111331111.content:
Mike thought about the news report and just shrugged. How was that even possible and what were the odds his dog would be infected. He sat down on a nearby bench and started reading a book while the dogs ran around and played...

Spike was easily the fastest dog I'm the park, easily running laps around the others. He quickly worked up a thirst so he stopped and drank some water out of the provided bowls. It wasn't as clean as his bowls at home but the parched husky didn't mind. After a few muzzle fulls he went back to running around, nosing a few other dogs to try to get them to chase him. Ashley time later Spike walked over to Mike and leaned on him panting rather heavily, seems the husky had tuckered himself out more quickly than normal.

Mike nodded and put his leash back on, walking back to the car Spike felt a tinge in his middle...
